Mudd Speaks Out
About The Media
BY MARK TRACHTENBERG
CBS-TV national affairs correspondent Roger Mudd spoke
in front of a nearly full house
at the annual Frank R. Kent
Memorial Lecture, held Wednesday evening in Shriver Hall. The
45-minute talk discussed the
relationship between the news
media and politics.
After being introduced by
University President Steven
Muller, Mudd opened his speech
with a series of mock news
bulletins. "President Carter has
just proposed merging the CIA
and the Postal Service," Mudd
announced, "since they already
open our mail, they might as
well deliver it." Mudd told of
Senator Edward Kennedy feeling
so hard-pressed for campaign
funds that he had resorted to
soliciting contributions at BWI
airport, and the Chrysler Corporation merging with New
York City to form an entity
called "The Big Lemon".
Mudd opened the serious
portion of his talk by saying he
had long been troubled by what
he termed the "Hollywood -star
reaction" of the public and

politicians to network reporters.
"We are seen far differently by
the public than we see ourselves," he explained. "People
view us as either saviors or
sinners."
Mudd told the audience that
the first indication of the change
in the media's role "from
spectator to player" was the
1964 Republican National Convention at the Cow Palace in San
Francisco, where many delegates
hooted and shook their fists at
network anchormen during a
speech which criticized the press
by former President Dwight D.
Eisenhower.
The Vietnam War further
transformed relations between
the media and government,
according to Mudd. "During
and after the war, we distrusted
the government more and the
government came to fear us," he
said. "It got to the point where
Vice President Agnew in the
infamous Des Moines speech
could call newsmen 'nattering
nabobs of negativism.' Of
course, we all know what
happened to him."

Fundamentalists Conspire to Take Over Paper
When it was learned that half the 12 members of
the Iowa State University Publications Board also
belonged to a fundamentalist Bible study group on
campus, reaction itself was almost biblical. It was swift,
if not altogether sure.
Journalists feared the religionists aimed to turn
the student-run Iowa State Daily, which the "pub
board" controls, into a self-consciously Christian
medium.
Faculty members of the board, worried
about the ease with which a special interest group got
into the position of control of the paper, announced
a boycott of board meetings. The county government
sued on the Daily's behalf. And members of the KSU
Bible Study Group, while protesting their innocence,
worried that the newspaper, in trying to stop special
interest groups from doing the same thing in the future,
may be discriminating agianst students on the basis
of their religion.
Though the Iowa State case is especially
dramatic, such controversies arise every spring, and
usually on more than one campus at a time. The
seasonal crop of April Fool's Day and humor issues
usually include material that one campus group or
another finds offensive. The offended group, in turn,
will raise the most difficult question in college
journalism: who should control the content of the
student newspaper?
At Iowa State, of course, the controversy did not
arise out of any expressions of newroom humor. But
most of the precedents that could determine the
outcome of what Daily staffers call a conspiracy arose
out of controversies over "joke journalism," according
to Mike Simpson of the Student Press Law Center in
Washington, D.C.
The range of response was evident last spring. In
April, for example, The Davidsonian, the student paper
at Davidson in North Carolina, published a satirical
"Guide to Courses"that was roundly criticized as
tasteless, especially by alumni and administrators.
But the price of offending student newspaper
readers is often higher. What Simpson describes as "a
very conservative group" is sponsoring a referendum to
cut off student funding for the Daily Tarheal at the
University of North Carolina-Chapel Hill.
Nothing seems to cause controversy more readily

than humorous religious references in a student paper,
however. A University of Minnesota Daily mock
interview with Jesus Christ was blasted as
"anti-religious" and "racist", and lead to yet another
fund cutoff referendum. It was recently defeated by a
two-to-one margin.

when the Observation Post at the City University of New
York published a picture of a woman in a scanty nun's
habit masturbating with a crucifix. Students voted to
cut off the paper's funding in retaliation. The picture
also brought on a bill in the New York legislature that
would have cut off funding for student papers at all
state schools. The bill actually passed the Senate, but
failed in the House.
